request_pathways.name: Authorization to Use or Disclose PHI (Records Request Form 2020)
Patient portal (electronic delivery option referenced on form)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: A single generic HIPAA authorization form with a 'Patient Access' checkbox among other third-party release purposes.

red_flags: Blanket liability waiver bundled into authorization with no opt-out
No submission instructions — form lacks any address, fax number, or email for where to send the completed form
Typo 'IDS' instead of 'AIDS' uncorrected since 2017 revision
bright_spots: Concise single-page form fitting all necessary content without being cramped
Clear voluntariness statement: patient told signing is not required for treatment
Easy online findability with clearly labeled Patient Forms page

findability.rationale: Level 5: Prominently available on a well-organized Patient Forms page with clear 'Medical Records Release' label; also found immediately via web search.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 2: Primarily a paper workflow — the PDF has zero fillable fields requiring print-and-handwrite, and the form provides no submission instructions (no fax number, address, or email), making electronic submission unclear.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized single-page layout with logical flow and clear section structure; minor issues include somewhat legalistic language and the absence of submission instructions.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form by selecting the 'Patient Access' checkbox, but the form was designed for third-party release — patients must navigate confusing recipient fields and a structure not built for self-access.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Bundled liability waiver goes beyond what is required for patient access; fee language is vague and doesn't distinguish patient-access requests; no expiration date field for one-time disclosures; no response time commitment.

overall.summary: An easily findable but paper-era generic authorization form that accommodates patient self-access as an afterthought rather than designing around it, with notable gaps in submission guidance and compliance language.
